verses.text: Now the apostles and the brothers who were throughout Judea heard that the Gentiles also had received the word of God.
verses.comment: This verse shows that the early Christian community quickly learned what was happening among the Gentiles. Emphasizes the spread of the Gospel beyond Jews, fulfilling Jesus' command in Acts 1:8.

verses.text: When Peter went up to Jerusalem, those who were of the circumcision party criticized him,
verses.comment: Shows early tensions regarding the church’s outreach to Gentiles, highlighting issues of tradition and inclusion.

verses.text: saying, "You went to men who are uncircumcised and ate with them."
verses.comment: Relates to Jewish food laws (Leviticus 11) and the significance of table fellowship as an act of unity and acceptance.

verses.text: But Peter began and explained it to them in order:
verses.comment: Peter provides a detailed personal testimony—a model of apostolic leadership clarifying doctrinal matters.

verses.text: "I was in the city of Joppa, praying, and in a trance I saw a vision: something like a large sheet coming down, being lowered from heaven by its four corners, and it came down to me.
verses.comment: The vision from God symbolizes the breaking down of barriers between Jews and Gentiles, reinforcing universal salvation.

verses.text: As I looked closely I observed animals and beasts of prey and reptiles and birds of the air.
verses.comment: The mention of unclean animals recalls the Old Testament dietary commandments, which are being fulfilled and reinterpreted in Christ.

verses.text: And I heard a voice saying to me, 'Rise, Peter; kill and eat.'
verses.comment: God personally commands Peter, showing apostolic authority relies upon divine revelation.

verses.text: But I said, 'By no means, Lord; for nothing common or unclean has ever entered my mouth.'
verses.comment: Peter’s response echoes Old Testament prophets. His respect for divine law is made complete through new revelation.

verses.text: But the voice answered a second time from heaven, 'What God has made clean, you must not call common.'
verses.comment: A paradigm shift in the relationship between ritual law and God’s revelation—a sign of the Apostolic authority to bind and loose (see Matt 16:19).

verses.text: This happened three times, and everything was drawn up again into heaven.
verses.comment: Repetition (three times) emphasizes certainty and importance, reminiscent of Peter’s denials and restoration (John 21:15-17).

verses.text: At that very moment, three men arrived at the house where we were, sent to me from Caesarea.
verses.comment: Details show God’s providential timing and continued guidance through the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: And the Spirit told me to go with them, making no distinction. These six brothers also went with me, and we entered the man's house.
verses.comment: The Spirit directs the mission, and witnesses accompany Peter, aligning with the biblical requirement for multiple witnesses (Deut 19:15).

verses.text: He told us how he had seen an angel stand in his house and say, 'Send to Joppa and bring Simon who is called Peter.'
verses.comment: Angelic visitations validate divine interventions in Church history, echoing angelic roles throughout salvation history (Luke 1:19).

verses.text: 'He will declare to you a message by which you will be saved, you and all your household.'
verses.comment: Salvation comes through the apostolic message. Households being saved allude to the biblical pattern of family-based faith (see Ex 12, Acts 16:15,33).

verses.text: As I began to speak, the Holy Spirit fell on them just as on us at the beginning.
verses.comment: Emphasizes God's initiative. Echoes the outpouring of the Spirit at Pentecost—Gentile believers are fully incorporated into the one Church.

verses.text: And I remembered the word of the Lord, how he said, 'John baptized with water, but you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit.'
verses.comment: Apostolic preaching recalls Jesus' words with authority and connects the sacramental action of baptism with the gift of the Spirit.

verses.text: If then God gave the same gift to them as he gave to us when we believed in the Lord Jesus Christ, who was I that I could stand in God's way?
verses.comment: Peter submits his will to God's. Reinforces the unity of the Church under God's singular plan of salvation through Christ.

verses.text: When they heard these things, they fell silent. And they glorified God, saying, 'Then to the Gentiles also God has granted repentance leading to life.'
verses.comment: The assembly’s recognition of God's work shows the Church’s unity and apostolic authority in matters of doctrine. Fulfillment of prophecy concerning Gentile salvation (Isa 49:6).

verses.text: Now those who were scattered because of the persecution that arose over Stephen traveled as far as Phoenicia, Cyprus, and Antioch, speaking the word to no one except Jews.
verses.comment: Shows how persecution advanced the spread of the Gospel and the initial Jewish focus of early preaching.

verses.text: But some of them, men of Cyprus and Cyrene, who came to Antioch, also began speaking to the Greeks, preaching the Lord Jesus.
verses.comment: The Gospel crosses cultural lines, highlighting the missionary dimension and universality of the Church.

verses.text: And the hand of the Lord was with them, and a great number who believed turned to the Lord.
verses.comment: The sign of success is tied to the Lord’s presence, reinforcing the significance of supernatural guidance in evangelization.

verses.text: The report of this came to the ears of the church in Jerusalem, and they sent Barnabas to Antioch.
verses.comment: Highlights Jerusalem’s centrality and authority. Missions are monitored and directed by the apostolic community.

verses.text: When he came and saw the grace of God, he was glad, and he encouraged them all to remain faithful to the Lord with steadfast purpose.
verses.comment: Barnabas, known for encouragement, strengthens new believers. Grace is visible in the life of the Church.

verses.text: For he was a good man, full of the Holy Spirit and of faith. And a great many people were added to the Lord.
verses.comment: Barnabas is described in terms similar to Old Testament and New Testament saints—holiness, faith, and fruitfulness as marks of true apostolic ministry.

verses.text: So Barnabas went to Tarsus to look for Saul,
verses.comment: Shows intentional efforts to involve other leaders; underscores fellowship and unity among apostles.

verses.text: and when he had found him, he brought him to Antioch. For a whole year they met with the church and taught a great many people. And in Antioch the disciples were first called Christians.
verses.comment: The term 'Christian' first applied to the Church shows visible identity and unity; teaching and tradition are central to apostolic ministry.

verses.text: Now in these days prophets came down from Jerusalem to Antioch.
verses.comment: Prophetic ministry continues within the Church, exercising spiritual gifts for the good of the body.

verses.text: And one of them, named Agabus, stood up and foretold by the Spirit that there would be a great famine over all the world (this took place in the days of Claudius).
verses.comment: Fulfilled prophecy validates the Spirit’s work. The community responds as one body to a global need, reminiscent of Joseph’s ministry during Egypt’s famine (Gen 41).

verses.text: So the disciples, each according to his ability, determined to send relief to the brothers living in Judea.
verses.comment: Early practice of organized charity, emphasizing a unified, sacrificial care for the community—a sign of true faith (Jas 2:15-17).

verses.text: They did this, sending it to the elders by the hand of Barnabas and Saul.
verses.comment: Funds are entrusted to recognized leaders—showing trust in apostolic authority and the importance of Church order (see Acts 14:23 for the role of elders).
